EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supersedes IRM 8.11.7 dated 10-29-2013 (effective MM-DD-YYYY). Incorporated Interim Memorandum AP-08-0714-0004, Implementation of the Appeals Judicial Approach and Culture (AJAC) Examination and General Matters - Phase 2, which was issued July 2, 2014, into this IRM.

IRC 6708 - Failure to Maintain Lists of Advisees with Respect to Reportable Transactions
) This section provides procedural and processing guidance on abusive tion penalties worked in Appeals. (

) Abusive transaction penalties are asserted to stop fraudulent, unscrupulous and/or incompetent tax return preparers, abusive transaction promoters, material advisors who fail to furnish information or maintain lists with reportable transactions. ″ ″ ″ ″ (

) The terms post-assessed and pre-assessed are used throughout this section. When a penalty is immediately assessable and is assessed prior coming to Appeals, it is considered a post-assessed penalty subject to assessment appeal rights. When a penalty is not assessed prior to coming Appeals, it is considered a pre-assessed penalty subject to pre-assessment appeal rights. Generally, the penalties in this section are post-assessed are not subject to deficiency procedures. (
) For the purposes of this section, the acronyms used for Appeals Technical Employees are ATEs, Account and Processing Support is APS, and Centralized Database System is ACDS. (
) The ATE should research the Appeals Website to determine if the issue is Appeals coordinated issue and if there is a Subject Matter Expert to the issue. (
) If the penalty is a coordinated issue: (cid:
) Add Feature Codes “AI” and “IT” when the coordinated issue is first fied. Either APS or ATE may update ACDS with the Feature Codes. (cid:
) If the ATE has a penalty issue that is coordinated, the ATE must make a referral to Appeals Technical Guidance through their manager upon ment or preliminary review using Form
, Appeals Technical Referral. For more information on coordinated issues, see IRM
, liminary Review of a Case-ATE, and IRM
Technical Guidance and International Programs. (cid:
) Appeals employees must secure review and concurrence from the Technical Specialist before finalizing any resolution of the issue, the penalty computation. (
) The ATE considers appeals of abusive transaction penalties in the same manner as appeals of any other proposed liability not subject to the of the procedures of subchapter B of Chapter
of the Internal Revenue Code. (
) There may be two case files: a penalty case file and a related income tax Technical file. Each case file will be a separate work unit and may come separately Appeals. (
) The statute of limitations may be different on the income case and the case for pre-assessed penalties. (
) The ATE should use the following forms to process Abusive Transaction Penalty Cases unless noted in a specific penalty section: (cid:

(10-01-2012) IRC 6707 - Failure to Furnish Information Regarding Transactions
Penalties Worked in (
) IRC
A penalties are one of several “stand-alone” penalties (penalties that do not require an associated income tax examination) that are not be subject to deficiency procedures. IRC
A penalties are assessable penalties with no reasonable cause exceptions. The
A penalty is in addition to any penalty that may be imposed and applies without regard to whether the trans- action ultimately results in an underpayment. (
) Generally, IRC
A penalty cases originate in Compliance [Large Business and International (LB&I), Small Business Self Employed (SBSE) or Tax Exempt/Government Entities (TE/GE)]. See IRM
, Operating Division IRC
A Functional Procedures. (
) Compliance Examiners are responsible for identifying income tax returns to which the IRC
A penalty applies. Examiners are responsible for to Appeals both the related unagreed income tax return case and the IRC
A penalty case. If the income tax case is agreed, only the IRC penalty case is submitted to Appeals, but it must include a copy of the income tax return and related documents. (
) Once the
-day letter is issued, the taxpayer or an authorized representative can request that Appeals consider the proposed penalty by filing a protest Compliance. (
) An IRC
A penalty and/or the underlying liability income tax case may not be submitted to Appeals if there are less than
days remaining on the statute of limitations. If Appeals returns a case to Examination with new evidence or new issues, there must be at least
days remaining on the statute of limitations when the case is received in Exam. Examination may return the case to Appeals with less than
days remaining on the statute limitations when received in Appeals. (
) If the statutory period for assessment of the IRC
A penalty is about to expire and the taxpayer will not agree to an extension, complete Form
have the penalty assessed and continue consideration of the case giving the taxpayer post-assessment appeal rights. (
) If both the underlying income tax liability issue and the IRC
A penalty appealed, Compliance will mail both case files to the appropriate Field Office according to the zip code routing instructions posted on the Appeals web site. Compliance should send the

A case to Appeals when the protest is received and should not “hold” the case pending receipt of a protest in any income tax case. Similarly, if the income tax case is completed and a protest is received, Compliance should send that case to Appeals and should not “hold” the case pending completion of the
A case and receipt of the
A protest. (
) If the underlying income tax liability issue is agreed, Compliance will forward only the appealed IRC

A penalty case to the appropriate Field Appeals Office, according to the zip code routing instructions posted on the Appeals web site. Compliance will include the taxpayer’s protest and copies of the following documents in the penalty case file: (cid:
) original filed income tax return (cid:
) Power of Attorney, if any (cid:
) agreement form (cid:
) current transcripts of income tax return Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) If the penalty relates to a non-listed reportable transaction, the ATE forwards (
) the copy of the penalty file to LB&I Pre-Filing Technical Guidance Joint ATE Closing Actions Committee per IRM
for potential rescission request. See IRM
, Rescission Requests. (
) If the penalty relates to a listed transaction and the taxpayer is a publicly traded company, Appeals should send a copy of the Form
and attach- ments to the Office of Tax Shelter Analysis (OTSA). OTSA will review to compliance with IRC
A(e) which provides for disclosures to the and Exchange Commission (SEC) where a taxpayer has an SEC reporting quirement and has participated in a listed transaction.
) Unlike most other penalties, IRC
A allows the Commissioner to rescind (

) the imposition of the penalty with respect to reportable non-listed Rescission Requests if it would “promote compliance with the tax laws and effective tax tion.” The penalty cannot be rescinded with respect to a listed transaction. A decision to rescind must be accompanied by a record describing the facts, reasons for the decision and the amount rescinded. (

) While a taxpayer may challenge, in Appeals and in court, the determination that it engaged in a reportable transaction or that it failed to timely and ad- equately disclose its participation in such a transaction, it cannot seek such review of the Commissioner’s refusal to rescind the penalty. (11-20-2014) Carding Procedures for IRC 6707A Penalty Cases
Moved APS general guidelines for closing these penalty cases on ACDS to IRM 8.20.7.13.1, Abusive Transaction IRC 6707A Penalty Closing
If the penalty relates to a non-listed reportable transaction, the ATE forwards the copy of the penalty file to LB&I Pre-Filing Technical Guidance Joint Committee per IRM
for potential rescission request. See IRM
, Rescission Requests. If the penalty relates to a listed transaction and the taxpayer is a publicly traded company, Appeals should send a copy of the Form
and attach- ments to the Office of Tax Shelter Analysis (OTSA). OTSA will review to compliance with IRC
A(e) which provides for disclosures to the and Exchange Commission (SEC) where a taxpayer has an SEC reporting quirement and has participated in a listed transaction. Unlike most other penalties, IRC

A allows the Commissioner to rescind the imposition of the penalty with respect to reportable non-listed if it would “promote compliance with the tax laws and effective tax tion.” The penalty cannot be rescinded with respect to a listed transaction. A decision to rescind must be accompanied by a record describing the facts, reasons for the decision and the amount rescinded. While a taxpayer may challenge, in Appeals and in court, the determination that it engaged in a reportable transaction or that it failed to timely and ad- equately disclose its participation in such a transaction, it cannot seek such review of the Commissioner’s refusal to rescind the penalty. The IRS is
required to submit an annual report to Congress summarizing the application of the IRC 6707A penalty and the rescission provision.
of the IRC

A penalty and the rescission provision. a. The Deputy Commissioner for Services and Enforcement will be the responsibility to determine for the Commissioner whether to the penalty in part or in full. b. The taxpayer must seek rescission within
days of notice and or full payment of the penalty, whichever is earlier. c. Currently, a taxpayer may seek rescission only if: (cid:
) the Service did not offer an opportunity to go to Appeals prior to ment of the penalty; (cid:
) Appeals has concluded its consideration of the issue; or (cid:
) the taxpayer has, in writing, both waived its right to such consideration conceded its liability for the penalty. d. Listed reportable transactions are not eligible for rescission Rev. Proc.

, provides detailed information how a taxpayer will seek rescission and factors that will support a request. Rescission requests should be sent to the address listed at IRM
). This penalty is imposed on any person required to maintain a list under
(a), Material advisors of reportable transactions must keep list of advisees, etc., who fails to make such list available. These cases are con- trolled on ACDS with TYPE Code =
See IRM
, Failure to Maintain Lists of Advisees with Respect to portable Transactions. A material advisor who fails to make the list available upon written request the Service within
business days after the request will be subject to a penalty of $
for each day of such failure after the
th business The penalty does not apply for any day where the failure to comply is due reasonable cause.
